dialogues.text: An original “Star Wars” LIGHT SABRE mounted on the wall.. the handle, a signature in black marker: George Lucas. Light from a Tiffany lamp on a bedside nightstand. The bed-- a homemade contraption -- atop a mechanical fra a queen mattress curled over on itself lengthwise to form shape not unlike a hollowed out log. Chris tucked inside. Chris lies snug in the bed, studies a poster on the oppos wall; ADULT FACES, subtle expressions-- surprise, anger, confusion. Joy. Chris mimics joy, puts a hand to his mout feels his smile. Lets it fade. He works a remote control and a small motor whirs, rotati the bed upward, mattress flattening. On his back now, eye resting on a large framed JACKSON POLLOCK mounted flush t the ceiling. He daydreams, lost in chaotic swirls of viscous paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Small. Institutional. BUNK BEDS. Bottom bunk, beneath a thin sheet FRANCIS SILVERBERG, 80s, bare-chested and frail, instructs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (New York accent) You’re not listening to the inflection. In. Flec. Tion. I say-- (stage melancholy) “I'm another year older, I don’t think I'll ever get out of this place.” Then you say...?  19. In the top bunk, Chris, t-shirt, mulls the question.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You’re probably right.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: What? No! That’s what you say? “You're probably right?”

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Given your age, it’s unlikely Two years together. Every you’11-- night.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: I give you a PhD in black money but can’t... He trails off. Silence. Chris considers his friend’s tone

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You're frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (pleased; loud) Yes! Yes! I’m frustrated! Excellent! Finally! Chris smiles. A BANG on the door. They ignore the intrusion. Francis quiets, turns reflective.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Friday would've been Esther's and my fiftieth. We were so poor. She couldn’t afford a gown, borrowed a blue suit that her cousin wore when she worked the cosmetic counter at Woolworths. Blue. But as Esther liked to say--

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS CHRIS
dialogues.text: “I was worthy of white.” “I was worthy of white.” Francis laughs; at the memory, his repetition. Chris smil pleased to have made Francis laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Boy, was she worthy. I think it’s why our engagement was so short, my balls were a lovely shade of blue. Chris puzzled by the shade of Francis’ testicles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: My Esther. She’d have liked you. So very much. Chris considers this for a long beat.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Why what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Would she have liked us? Francis recognizes the flash of depression, feels for him

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: One day you'll see an opportunity to slide out of here. Memorize the names I gave you? The numbers?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: They’1l get you started, give you work. Try to find one person to help you, to trust. One. You’1l have to rely on word of mouth, your reputation, for new business. Don’t try to separate saints from sinners, we’re all sinners. People keep secrets, numbers release them; if the secrets are too big, killing you to keep them may be the cost of doing business. There’s honor among thieves but it helps if they know you’1l scorch the Earth if they fuck with you... remember the Mad Hatter.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We remember. Francis pauses, his mood softens, reflective.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Try not to make the same mistake I did; always keep moving. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: And you’re gonna have to toughen up, learn how to protect yourself. Your generation’s too soft.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’ve got that covered.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: (chuckles) Sure you do. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re all just dashes on headstones, kid. “Life is lived between the numbers.” Famous Jew?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Kafka?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: Francis Silverberg, putz! Miami Beach, 1983! Eulogizing the late great Meyer Lansky! Francis HOWLS, shoves the bottom of Chris’ bunk. Chris smiles. LOUD BANGING at the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: HEY! Lights out, in there!

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS
dialogues.text: HEY! Fuck you, out there! Francis turns on his side, settles in with a SIGH.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got a new handler today. A little dull. Worries me a bit. We'll see. G’night, son. Chris concerned. He wears boxers, no sheet, around an ank a DIGITAL MONITOR, its red light blinks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Good night, Francis.

dialogues.speaker: RETURN TO
dialogues.text: On the nightstand, Chris’ MOBILE RINGS. He sits up, instantly alert. He connects, pauses...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Go. On the other end of the phone a COMPUTER KEYBOARD CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone; flat) Enough with the dramatics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris sits, laptop open on the table. He watches the scre the images change constantly, rapidly:  22.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) What about Zurich? Saudi Arabia? B&W PHOTO: 1960s M.I.T. Engineering class, ONE MAN CIRCLE

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone; even tone) The Swiss are cheap, they’re on a net ninety schedule. Dubai’s one thing but we’re too conspicuous in The Kingdom. I vote Chicago. NEWSPAPER CLIPPING: 1970s, LAMAR BLACK, a young Silicon Valley greaser in a garage-workshop.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’re not sure we like it.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There’s an uptick in online chatter. People searching for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What people? POLAROID: a small storefront shop: “CREATIVE ROBOTICS.”

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE
dialogues.text: The unfriendly kind. It would be interesting to try a legitimate client for once. No cartels, arms brokers, money launderers, assassins. I like safe. I like you safe.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: There’s honor among thieves. FORTUNE ARTICLE/PHOTO: 1980s, Lamar and his older sister pose with a prototype robot.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There’s honor among Illinois electronics manufacturers. VIDEO of clean-room manufacturing.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They’1l pay with a cashier’s check and they’re in your current backyard; no risk of movement. You’1l meet? PHOTO: Vegas Consumer Electronics Show: STEVE JOBS and La

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We'll meet.  23.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One last piece of business. YOUTUBE: a Humvee convoy in Iraq disappears in a massive fireball as an I.E.D. DETONATES.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Just the Renoir.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t have a buyer for the Renoir. The Pollock we can move. Will you ever let it go? Chris quiets, the images on his laptop screen grim. PHOTOS: Iraq/Afghanistan war vets lie in hospital beds, f cut, burned, their shortened arms and legs bandaged. PHOTOS: sutured STUMPS of a dozen amputated arms-legs. CNN: a rehab patient’s prosthetic fingers pick up a DIME.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello? Chris looks away, focuses on the Renoir, takes comfort in

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Drop the price. We could use the deduction.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Heavy sigh. Go to work you aspie dreamboat. (disconnects)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A granite “CREATIVE ROBOTICS” sign on a tree-lined campus leads to a large ultra-modern glass structure. The sound of two people walking fast, talking fast...

dialogues.speaker: ED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bad idea, worse timing. Not one of your brother's better ideas.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (annoyed; hard) Deep breath, Ed. Companies hire outside auditors every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electromechanical arms slide computer chips onto circuit boards, automated arms solder.  24.

dialogues.speaker: ED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: From Pricewaterhouse, Rita. Ernst and Young! What kind of “auditor” comes recommended by an Albanian war criminal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, suit and tie, pocket protector, stands compliant, outstretched. A SECURITY GUARD waves a metal-detector bat over him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Apparently, the kind who produces results.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RITA BLACK, 60s, handsome and EDWIN “ED” CHILTON, 60s, la no smile, sit together, face Chris across a large table.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: No C.V.? Project list?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, ma’‘am.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Client list?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: (snorts) Anything?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Newsletter?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You have a newsletter?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No, sir. Rita cracks a smile. Chris stares back, parrots the smile

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Uh, Mr. Wolff, I half suspect we’re wasting your time.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We're certain you’re not.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: (defensive) And you know this how?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We're on the clock.  25. Rita’s smile reaches her eyes. Chris lifts his briefcase onto the table, pops locks, lid

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: (insincere laughter) Well, shit, I hope we’re not wasting ours then. (changes tactics) Kidding aside, I think if you saw our books you’d run for the hills. Chris silently mouths the expression, confused.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: We have an incredibly complicated accounting system. Chris stirs, senses a challenge. A PUZZLE.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Depreciation schedules on hundreds of different items, charge-backs, full-time and contract employees, Department of Defense classified accounts... a numerical shit-storm-- He’s in.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’ll need your books for each of the last ten years, a complete list of vendors and clients for that same period, bank statements and two dry erase boards. Extra large. It’s all here. Chris pulls a sheet of paper from a folder, slides the itemized list to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Whoa now. This was all brought to my attention only last week. A junior cost accountant stuck her nose where it didn’t belong and obviously had no idea what she was looking at. Lamar’s overreacting, there is no missing money!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Never hurts to be sure. She traps Ed with a confrontational look.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (reads; to Ed) This org chart shows you as the CFO for the last fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The books for the last fifteen. The air is sucked from the room. Ed turns hostile.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Well, you’re awful Goddamn blunt. Chris glances at him, unfazed by Ed’s anger.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I’m Lamar Black’s oldest friend. I’ve been by his side since he was turnin’ out RC robots Radio Shack called crap. I wouldn’t take a dime without his say so.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You’re angry.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: This is bullshit. Rita stares at Chris, holds a hand up to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You charge a retainer of one hundred thousand plus two and a half percent of all tracked funds? Chris maintains eye contact, nods.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: “Tracked?” Not recovered?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’re an accountant, not a repo- man.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: (sotto; sarcastic) “We're an accountant”?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Unusual way of making contact with you, Mr. Wolff. He blinks at her, not reacting to her tone.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I.T. tells me the address was probably routed through Moscow. She studies him. Nothing. Considers her words. 26.  27.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: We custom made prosthetics for Mr. Haradinaj’s youngest daughter. Maybe you’re aware -- she lost both legs to a car bomb in Kosovo. He told my brother you were nothing short of supernatural. His word. (meaningful beat) Tell me, what type of accounting does one do for a former KLA warlord wanted by The Hague? Silence. The question hangs. Chris looks away, then back.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We don’t discuss client business. She stares at him for a beat, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall clock reads 4:03, the division hums with activity. At her bullpen desk, Marybeth stares at her monitor, scro through profiles of the THUGS in the Accountant file. Faces flash, words, figures pop: Terrorist. Hawala. $20 million. Extortion. $45 million. Organized crime. Smurfing. $70 million. Narcotics kingpin. Murder. She pushes back, anxious, looks around the beehive. MARYBETH’S POV -- every person busy, on the phone, comput engaged. Ray paces in his office, phone pressed to the si of his head, giving someone hell. Pressure. She pulls back to her desk, determined. Clicks her mouse, brings up the ANTWERP photo, locates the Accountant. She MAPS his face, SLIDES THE DIGITAL IMAGE to a desktop folder. Opens her e-mail, types in the “to” box: SORKIS@DHS.GOV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris looks through one-way glass as a WHITE-COATED DOCTO works on one of two prosthetic arms on a seated shirtless (and armless) MAN, 20s. The prosthetic is Terminator-high-tech. Chris turns as LAMAR BLACK, 60s, enters the viewing room. Lamar, in khaki pants, plaid shirt, oozes decency, warmth Lamar stands next to Chris, watches the lab. The doctor removes one arm and walks to a side bench. The patient looks off-balance without the arm, incomplete.  28.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: What do you think that young man is thinking right now? Chris watches the man sit on his stool, stare into space.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Why do I still feel my arm? How did everything go so wrong so fast? (sympathetic beat) Where did I go? Silence as the two study the man.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (serious) Can someone please turn up the heat? Lamar grins, turns to Chris, impressed. He extends a hand

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Christian Wolff, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Black.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Lamar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Techs manipulate robotic arms, legs, joints. A prosthetic armed patient picks coins off a table with robotic finger Chris and Lamar walk and talk.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Are you aware of Creative’s three income streams, Chris?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Consumer electronics, next generation prosthetics, unmanned military applications. The consumer division matured three years ago after twenty-five years as your largest producer. Now the prosthetics and Department of Defense contracts are one and two.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: (smiles ) Do you know why the prosthetics division is increasing?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Medical advancements.  29. Lamar looks at him, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: In Vietnam, the survival rate of a soldier with a catastrophic injury was one in twenty. Now, if an I.E.D. hits a convoy in Afghanistan, twelve hours later they’re in a hospital in Germany. Then there’s an increase in obesity causing a spike in diabetes, which often leads to amputations. Land- mine proliferation, accidents-- Lamar stops walking, turns to Chris.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: You’re unusually well informed. Chris blinks at Lamar, doesn’t respond to the compliment.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: I never married. Never had kids. This company is my child. I was blessed to have a sister ina position to provide start-up capital, but money has never been my motivation. I’m not a religious man, Chris, but I can see the hand of God in what we do. We have a social purpose. Whatever you need to do your job, you let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of someone typing fast. SUPER: Department of Homeland Security SORKIS, a tech, Lebanese, 20s, gamer-style, headset on, s and stares at the center of 3 desk monitors.

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS
dialogues.text: (into phone; defensive) It’s an algorithm I designed and don’t tell me how to do my job. His fingers pound the wireless keyboard on his lap. On a side monitor: Marybeth’s unsmiling face superimposed a VIRTUAL POLE DANCING STRIPPER. Center monitor: the ANTWERP PHOTO, BEING MAPPED WITH GEOMETRIC PLANES. On the last monitor: CALL OF DUTY/BLACK OPS.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty except for Marybeth at her desk, phone to an ear.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (into phone; irritated) Why are you running any algorithms, Sorkis? As you can plainly see, I already mapped and smoothed it. All you have to do--

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) I plainly see you fat-fingered it with an archaic 3-D model. And you don’t run this through Treasury's data base because?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Because Homeland has everybody’s files; NSA, the Bureau, Spooks... we don’t have dick around here.

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did you just say “di-- She disconnects, stress getting to her. INT. CREATIVE ROBOTICS - CHRIS’ OFFICE - MORNING Chris, in a suit, carrying a briefcase, steps inside a converted conference room. Two large dry-erase boards fill a wall. Lined on a long table, tall neat stacks of files. A plate of carefully arranged doughnuts, napkins, coffee. SNORING. Hidden by the files, a woman, 20s, business suit sits slumped forward, head down on the table, sleeping. Chris watches her for a beat, unsure how to proceed.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (clears throat) Hello? She shifts, her snoring slows, stops, starts.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Hello. Ma’am? Nothing. He looks at the doorway, no assistance. He studies her for a beat. Pretty. He gently rocks her shoulder. Mostly-asleep, she swipes his hand away.  31. Chris circles, uncomfortable, deciding. He leans over, hi mouth to an ear, prepares a gentle whisper...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (shouts )

dialogues.speaker: GOOD MORNING
dialogues.text: DANA CUMMINGS, bolts up. Bookish-attractive, wild-eyed an dripping drool. She gets to her feet, unsteady. Chris steps back, out of his element.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (self-conscious; groggy) Hello. Good morning. I’m Dana. Dana Cummings. You’re the consultant? Mr. Wolff?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Chris. She wipes her mouth, pushes tangled hair out of her face.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Sorry. Chris, then. I’m Dana.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Cummings.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. That’s right. Chris remembers to smile, glances at the reports.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I made copies of all the files you wanted. Cross referenced them for you alphabetically and by year. Maintenance put in the boards.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. Awkward. He scans the room, searches for a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Must have taken you all night. Bleary, she gestures no big deal. Silence as he waits, reluctantly scours her face for a clue what to say, do.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Are... were you...?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Was I...?  Searching. For? You Awkward. 32.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Waiting for... Painful.

dialogues.speaker: DANA CHRIS
dialogues.text: to...? Us to say...?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (blurts ) What do you want, Dana Cummings?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (flinches) Oh, Mr. Black thought I could be of some help to you. I first spotted the missing... what I think are irregularities, I mean... (collects her thoughts) Some things just didn’t make sense--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We'll find it.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Right. Sure. You want to come to... make your own assessment. His eyes bounce around the room and back to her.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: If you'd like, if it would be helpful I mean, we could have lunch, and I could answer any questions you might have.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We brought lunch. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (grins) You have a mouse in your pocket?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled beat) No. We do not.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Uh, you said “we.” I was just... (regroups ) I bring my own lunch, too. Okay. Well, if you need anything, I’m down in Accounting. Embarrassed, she backs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Some doughnuts there for you.  33. He nods, bounces eye contact, produces a polite smile.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Absolutely no problem. She turns, glad to be leaving, exits. He walks to the door, closes it, relieved. He turns to th blank boards, energy building, eager to get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press conference in full swing. Cameras, REPORTERS. The SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY, 60s, mans a podium emblazo with the Treasury insignia. Flanking him, Ray, and a half dozen agents. Marybeth stands in a crowd at the rear of the room.

dialogues.speaker: TREASURY SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (pointing to a reporter) Yes, Helen?

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER 1
dialogues.text: (stands) Sir, how did you first discover Al- Qaeda was funneling money into these charitable fronts?

dialogues.speaker: TREASURY SECRETARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why don’t I turn this over to the head of the task force and the man most responsible for these arrests. Financial Crimes Deputy Director, Raymond King. Cameras click, reporters SHOUT questions. Ray grips the podium top, at ease, in command. The room quiets.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Folks, there’s no mystery here. Marybeth’s MOBILE VIBRATES inside her purse.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nothing fancy. Just a team effort comprised of long hours of good old- fashioned investigative work. Questions. The room ERUPTS with shouting reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marybeth bangs out of the Press Room, answers her mobile.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (into phone; brusque) Give me something, Sorkis.

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (over phone Ordinarily I'd jump all over-- (background noise spikes) Oh! God, that gives me the heebies every time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorkis hidden by a cluster of standing TECH GEEKS who cro his cubicle, all staring at his monitors. AUDIO: car tires SCREECH, horns BLARE.

dialogues.speaker: FEDERAL AGENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (at a distance; shouts) Wait, let me call it in! The group hushed, shocked faces. IMPRESSED faces.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (slowing) Who is that? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS
dialogues.text: I matched the face in your Antwerp photo to a surveillance video in the NYPD database.

dialogues.speaker: TECH 1
dialogues.text: (awed; low) Again. Play it again. Sorkis, headset on, stares at his monitors. All three screens synced for a B&W SURVEILLANCE VIDEO. DON (aka Partner), a middle-aged plain-clothes cop, enter the frame, runs across the busy street, gun in hand, towa the Raven. He glances back at the camera. END VIDEO.

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS
dialogues.text: (into headset) M.B., babe, you gotta see this. Sorkis double-clicks his mouse.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (stops walking; urgent) The NYPD? What did you find? RAVEN FOOTAGE. Taken from across the street, an occasiona passing van or truck blocks the footage.  35. A slender man in a white shirt -- back to the camera -- w toward the Raven’s entrance. Flanking the Raven’s double doors, two large ENFORCERS. The Enforcers exchange glances, push off the building, mo to block the man. Enforcer 1 extends an arm toward the man. The Techs grimace, BRACE. IMPOSSIBLY FAST -- the man grabs Enforcer 1's straightene arm, jerks him close, his free hand darting to the big ma neck... PIVOTS around him... a MINI-VAN passes. Enforcer 1 sinks to his knees, shocked, clawing at the ST KNIFE BURIED IN HIS THROAT. Enforcer 2 fumbles desperately under his jacket for a gun The man closes fast. Too fast. Enforcer 2 bails on the gun, loops a vicious roundhouse. The man ducks the swing, comes up with sharp jab to the Enforcer’s throat, stumbles him. Enforcer 2 clutches his shattered larynx. The man grips Enforcer 2's head, forcing him down, snappi his own knee up into the Enforcer’s face. CRUNCH. OS: brakes lock, TIRES SCREECH, HORNS BLARE. Reaching under the slumping Enforcer’s jacket, the man EXTRACTS A PISTOL. The body hits the pavement. The man checks the gun’s slide for a chambered round. The man moves to the door. A brief pause as he pushes the bridge of his glasses up, enters the Raven.

dialogues.speaker: FEDERAL AGENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (at a distance; shouts) Wait, let me call it in! From inside the Raven, the muted sound of TWO QUICK GUN SHOTS. Silence. And then a FULL-BLOWN GUNFIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: SORKIS! Talk to me. What the hell do you have? Sorkis rewinds the footage. A mini-van reverses.  36.

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS
dialogues.text: Nine dead Corleones and a fifty three-point-three percent probability. On the center monitor the KILLER'S FACE frozen mid-pivot. could be Chris.

dialogues.speaker: SORKIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What in God’s name are you into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skyline of Canary Wharf. SUPER: London, England

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly empty. Clip of expensive shoes on concrete. A HEDG FUND boss - 30s, fit, handsome - walks, presses his key f a car alarm beeps. He frowns at a sight os.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: (sotto; Brit accent) Son of a bitch. He reaches his reserved spot; a plain sedan parked inches from the driver’s side of his Aston Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hedge Funder drags a leg over the center console, folds himself into the driver’s seat just as BRAXTON “BRAX” - 3 handsome, suit jacket, slacks, no tie - slides into the passenger seat, closes the door. Brax points a suppressor equipped .45 at Hedge Funder.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ great. (weary; pulls wallet) I’m late, sport, let’s move this along shall we? I’ve roughly fifteen hundred on me. (displays a watch) Audemars Piguet, forty thousand. The car’s worthless to you, you can’t unload an Aston Martin. Not a One-77.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (American accent) Daniel Simmons, founder, CEO of Simmons Capital, third largest hedge fund in the U.K. Hello.  37.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: American. Shocking. I have kidnap insurance, you obviously know that.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Why would I know--

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: You fucking people amaze-- Brax’ free hand snakes -- SLAPS the man across the face. Hedge Funder startled by the quickness, power of the stri

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: When you interrupt me I think you’re not interested in what I have to say. That or you think what you have to say is more important. Which is it?

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: That gun make you feel like a big man does it? Brax rests the gun on the dash, whips his hand, SLAPS Hed Funder. The financier gasps, head swivels. Hedge Funder’s eyes water, then focus, blood trickles fro split lip. He glances at the free gun on the dash. Brax watches, pushes the gun an inch closer to the man.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I’m part of a small but potent department of a private security force. We have a client; a European manufacturing concern. You’re shorting their stock while simultaneously spreading false rumors regarding the health of the company. The resulting decline of their stock price has made you millions at my client’s expense. They’ve been forced to lay off hundreds of employees; third generation metal-workers. People with families. Pensions are being rendered worthless because of you. You’1l stop now.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: Which company? Brax shakes his head, doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: Look, genius, how do I know who to--  38. Brax extraordinarily fast -- SLAP! -- Hedge Funder’s head jerks from the shot to the mouth. Hard glance at the gun.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: I only meant-- We hold short positions on dozens of manufacturers! Hedge Funder watches Brax edge the .45 closer.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I suppose if you’re spreading false information on more than one, you'll have to stop shorting all of them.

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: That’s ridiculous, I can’t-- SLAP! SLAP! Brax rocks him, quick, vicious. Hedge Funder’ face burns, tears well. He looks around for help.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Security’s not coming. They’re no longer ambulatory. He stares at Brax, tries not to look at the gun. Fails.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I’m not judging you. Doesn't matter to me how a man makes a living. In fact, here’s a stock tip, take the sting out: CLN; Coleman Company. Hundred years old, camping equipment, lanterns--

dialogues.speaker: HEDGE FUNDER
dialogues.text: I know who-- Hedge Funder catches himself, clams up. Brax lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: They make a wonderful cooler. Durable, stylish. Little ice, a few sodas, sandwiches, keeps cold for days. As a kid I would always know when it was time to move when my mom -- who was tighter than bark on a tree -- got out the Coleman and started emptying the fridge. Brax relaxes, remembering. Hedge Funder uses the moment t steal a look at the gun.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: We'd take that cooler into the Negev Desert for days. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The men we were with -- Shin Bet, the Mossad, a few Delta, occasionally Jordanian special forces -- they brought sniper rifles. But then they weren’t ten and twelve years old either. Brax slides the gun directly in front of Hedge Funder.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Maybe you're faster. Maybe you can find the safety before I take it away from you. Hey, maybe the safety’s already off and you can just point and squeeze. Or maybe in all the ruckus I pull the shiv tucked into my belt. Hedge Funder’s eyes dart to Brax’ waist line.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Plastic composite. Undetectable at airport security. Surgical sharp but strong enough to punch a hole through the roof of this fancy toy of yours. But maybe I’m bluffing. Decision. Hedge Funder sinks back in his seat, cowed.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Chin up. You made two-hundred ninety-six million last year. Ably navigated the hazards of arbitrage, futures and commodities markets. A success by any standard. (relaxes; leans back) About a week from now your testicles will descend. You'll rationalize your inaction this evening; tell yourself I caught you off guard, convince yourself you made the only play possible under the circumstance. That things would be different if we met on the street. But mainly you’ll find it hard to live with the fact that you’ve abandoned tens of millions based on a stylish threat and the palm of my hand. Then you’ll call your chief trader and tell him to resume your financial mischief. Hedge Funder lunges for the gun -- freezes -- a short BLA at his throat.  40.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (close; intense) At which point I’1l materialize out of thin air with a Coleman full of ice and a pair of rubber gloves. I‘1l open you up, dump your bowels on the floor and make a quick hundred grand harvesting what’s left. Hedge Funder trembles, tears run down his cheeks. Michael Buble's voice fills the car -- “I’ve got the worl a string, I’m sitting on a rainbow” -- Brax’ mobile. Brax retrieves his phone with his free hand, stares at He Funder, answers.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (into phone) Brax here... Forget it, you know I’ve a vacation scheduled. (winks at Hedge Funder) If I’m in and out in twenty-four hours... E-mail me the usual, and make it O’Hare, Midway's a sewer. Brax disconnects, pockets the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I’m an avid reader of the Journal. I expect your cooperation to be reflected there. We good? Hedge Funder swallows, blade against his Adam’s apple. No Brax sheathes his knife, collects his gun, exits the car. We hear the sedan start, see through the driver's window it pulls away. Slow. Hedge Funder hangs his head, sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ducks paddle across a man-made pond, circled with trees. Dana sits on one of two park benches facing the water. An insulated carry-all next to her, she eats a yogurt. Chris, sack lunch and thermos in hand, approaches the benches. She turns just as he sees her, slows. She inches her carry-all closer to her, making room. Frustration slides across his face, solitary routine compromised. He beelines for the empty bench, unpacks lun An awkward beat for Dana, then --

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Any progress?  41. He half nods, half shrugs, then turns from her, blows twi on his fingertips. He unwraps a sandwich, takes a bite, watches the ducks. H glances at Dana, back to the ducks. She cuts her eyes to him then the ducks.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: So, how did you get into the whole financial consulting thing? He swallows, hesitates, then grinds out a response.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: According to Department of Labor statistics, accounting services are among the top growth professions. She nods, unsure how to reply to this odd sterile answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The actuarial sciences should also continue to see high demand.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Uh... okay. She spoons some yogurt, hesitates, waits for the customar follow-up question. It doesn’t come.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I like, I like balance. But I really enjoy finding things. Things that are hidden. On purpose. Not that I get to doa lot of that-- He SIGHS, wanting her to get on with it. Dana stopped by the sigh, confused. Surely not.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: My father, he was an accountant. Had the whole schtick; little amortization book, green eye-shade-- (laughs; back on track) This dorky pocket protector he-- Both suddenly aware of Chris’ pocket protector. He looks at it, then to her, unfazed. She stammers--

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Not, not a nice one like yours. That one you’ve got, that’s really... something. (winces; trailing off) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He, uh, he talked me into-- encouraged, he encouraged me. Silence for a long beat. The ducks QUACK for scraps. She struggles to fill the dead space.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I wanted to study art. At the Art Institute of Chicago. But... He stops eating his sandwich, looks at her. He holds her gaze, for the first time interested.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: “Art won't pay the mortgage, young lady.” Dad’s tastes ran more to Dogs Playing Poker.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We like Dogs Playing Poker.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: No, I, I like Dogs Playing Poker, too, it’s just, you know, it’s not, real art. His blank stare throws her, she abandons her point.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I took accounting at the University of Chicago. “Where fun goes to die.” They sit in silence for a beat, Chris considers her words watches the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Why what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Does fun go to the University of Chicago to die? She pauses, not knowing if he’s screwing with her or not.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: It's just an express--—

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. We're kidding. She reddens, laughs, brief eye contact between them, smil  43.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why not do what makes you happy?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (beat; rationalizes) We do a lot of good here. Chris nods his understanding.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: My first week, I went down to the prosthetics lab. Mr. Black was working with a man, a boy really, Maybe nineteen, twenty tops. (somber beat) A Marine. Skin and bones. Both arms amputated at the shoulder. Depressed, wouldn’t eat. He watches her remember, sees the emotion rise.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: He put his arm around that boy and said, “Son, we can build you the fanciest arms you ever saw, but if you don’t start eating every thing your mother puts on your plate I’1l put my foot straight up your a--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Surface area. She clears her throat, embarrassed, her eyes wet.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The more surface area for the prosthetics to attach to, the better they work.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Surface area? What are you--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (enthused) The Marine. Mr. Black wanted him to gain weight in order for his new arms to fit effectively. She stares at him for a dumbfounded beat before zipping h carry-all. She stands, forces a tight smile.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Call me if you need anything. He watches her leave. Returns to the ducks. Pleased.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Surface area. Smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audio: A GUNFIGHT. Men curse in anger, shout in fear. SUPER: One Police Plaza, New York City Marybeth, headphones on, listens, absorbed by the audio violence. She sits to one side of a desk manned by... DON, 50s -- same guy on video -- stocky, shirt and tie, stares at the spiking audio waves on his desk monitor. He tap-tap-taps a pencil on his desk, annoyed, restless. The floor busy. Noisy. A mostly male, shirt-and-tie crowd Over her headphones: the gunfire stops, silence. Then--

dialogues.speaker: FRIGHTENED MAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over headphones; static) Stop! You’re not hearing me. I wasn’t even there! I didn’t touch that old man-- The audio ends.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That’s it. Anything else? She slides the phones off her ears and around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Help me understand. The subject shivs the fir--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Steak knife. From Amighetti’s. Catty-corner cross the street.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: In front of which you and your partner were parked, listening to a bugged Raven Social Club. Don nods, stares at his desk, tap-tap-taps his pencil.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Unofficial headquarters of the Gambino crime family. Another nod.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: He kills a second man, takes his weapon, enters -- for all intents and purposes, an armed fortress -- and kills another seven men. Using their weapons. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m telling you.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (incredulous beat) Who does that?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Not my problem. She can’t accept this, opens her mouth to say so--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I worked the Organized Crime Task Force. Whoever this guy was, he wasn’t Organized Crime. It was just him, and he ran the table on all our organized criminals.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: And you weren't a little curio--

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Place was a toilet. Somebody wants to work the flusher, fine by me.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (tiring of Don) Now, you’re an officer of the law. Don. And, if I recall the video footage correctly... armed. He smiles to himself, shakes his head... here it comes.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: You saw two men die. Watched their assailant arm himself, walk into a building you were surveilling, turn it into the corner butcher shop-- (blows across her palm) Pull a Keyser Soze, and all you can think to say is “fine by me?” Don wheels his chair close to her, looks around the room, leans in, conspiratorially. She leans in, closer.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (whispers) Fuck. You. Inches apart, their eyes lock, neither blink.  46.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (low; intense) This guy dismantled two mob enforcers -- known murderers -- in under five seconds. No huffing and puffing. No rolling around on the Sidewalk. He bled them out and strolled into a den of stone-cold killers like he was the Fed-Ex guy. He reaches into a bottom drawer, pulls out a file folder.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I have a wife, agent. Three kids. We drive to Gulf Shores every July. Not a great life, but it’s mine. He pulls a short stack of photos from the file, holds the to her, one by one: GRAPHIC KILL SHOTS of Raven victims.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Steak knife in the throat. Nasal bones in the brain. Head-shot. Head-shot. Head-shot. He stops, stares... the photo in his hands extra gruesome

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Somewhere along the line, got his hands on a cut-down twelve gauge. Shuffles the deck, another photo, another dead mobster.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Anthony “Little Tony” Benedetto. Acting capo of the family. Both orbital ridges splintered. Forensics lists cause of death as massive blunt force trauma. She looks from the photo to Don, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Kicked him. Once. He returns the photos to his desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: So you tell me, Treasury Barbie: who does that? He stands, pulls a pack of cigarettes from a shirt pocket

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Both you and Bloomberg can kiss my ass. I’1l be outside.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you pursue this guy?  47.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) What exactly do you do over there? Talk to King, you guys shut it down. Confused, she watches him leave. INT. CREATIVE ROBOTICS - CHRIS’ OFFICE - NIGHT Open briefcase contains files. Laptop. Pens. Tape. Two rows of dry-erase markers; a dozen RED, a dozen BLACK. All the LEDGERS open, spread out over the tables. Chris stands, bending over a ledger, running his hand quickly d the page, hunting. He flips the page, scans it, faster now... stops. He RIPS THE PAGE OUT. Chris stands, stares straight ahead, two markers -- red a black -- in his shirt pocket. Adrenaline flows, he rolls sleeves up, undoes a shirt button, tucks his tie in. In his mind, the faint notes of MUSIC from a hundred different sources, disjointed, growing louder. He pulls the markers, one in each hand. Practiced thumbs the caps. In front of him, two pristine dry-erase boards. The music coalesces, a specific BEAT emerges, swells.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: With two large BOLD SWIPES of the black marker he forms a accountant’s classic “T” account. Numbers and names go up. Ambidextrous, credits in black marker, debits in red. A ledger page in one hand, marker clenched between teeth, furiously transcribes figures onto the board. Ripped ledger pages drift to the floor, accumulate. Outside: workers file out, hit the parking lot, head home The board fills with thousands of numbers, names. His actions energetic, JOYOUS. Numbers stream sideways, up, down, angled. CHAOS. Chris talks to himself, voice modulating, singsong, fast, slow. Happy.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation. Earnings before interest. Tax. Depreciation. Tax. Depreciation. Tax, tax, tax. Ragged ledger pages taped to the walls.  48. Outside: nightfall. A single office window illuminated. His left hand connects a board-length red line to a set o figures, the right hand does the same with a black line. He LAUGHS, whips a spent marker across the room, advances the board, eyes it, twisting, bending, searching for fres perspective, the way in. LOVING it. The music builds. INT. MARYBETH’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - NIGHT Kitchen table. Unopened bills. Half-eaten T.V. dinner.

dialogues.speaker: FRIGHTENED MAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over laptop; static) Stop! You’re not hearing me. I wasn’t even there! I didn’t touch that old man-- Marybeth t-shirt, jeans, sits at the small table, stares the screen of a laptop: DIGITAL AUDIO SIGNATURES. She finger-swipes the pad, REWINDS. Digital waves spike t the sound of gunfire, screaming. She deletes each signatu wave, listens to static. Nothing. Tired, she leans back in her chair, eyes closed. She does see the WHISP of an audio spike on the monitor. Then-- A VOICE. Faint, ghostly. Her eyes snap open. She bangs he chair forward, hits REWIND, presses the UP volume key, ho it. Her ear to a tiny speaker... a voice, barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARYBETH’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM She cables her laptop to tall speakers. CRANKS IT. A LOUD HISS. She paces, hands in her hair. ANYTHING! Freezes as a WHISPERED CHANT FILLS THE ROOM--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Solomon Grundy born on a Monday. INT. CREATIVE ROBOTICS - CHRIS’ OFFICE - MORNING Dana stands in the doorway, staring. Stunned. The dry-erase boards (and a portion of wall) packed with and black. Thousands upon thousands of numbers, names. Th numbers collide, flow across the boards, some writ large, some small. Strangely BEAUTIFUL. A veritable FINANCIAL JACKSON POLLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands where both boards meet, lost in thought, repeatedly CIRCLING the sole empty space available.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (soft) Chris? He turns to her, his unshaven face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Come take a look! He’s across the room in a snap, grabs her wrist, and half walks, half drags a surprised Dana through hundreds of st ledger pages to the boards. She looks at his hands, his shirt, stained from marker. T destroyed annual reports.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It'll jump right out at you. She’s confronted with indecipherable boards.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (confused nod) Uh-huh. He moves quickly to the bottom far left hand side of the boards and a CIRCLED figure. Raps his knuckles on it.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Creative ten years ago. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation. He moves right, another circled figure, raps his knuckles

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Nine years ago. Sales increase, profit declines. Declines? Dana stares at him, at the board. Amazed. He moves about the board, underlining various numbers.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No large capital investments dragging profits down. No spike in raw materials, labor costs, tax. Continues to move, raps a third circle, and a fourth.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Eight years ago, seven. Sales up, profits up, but not at a comparable rate. X no longer equals Y. Her eyes race, trying to keep up but failing.  50. He SLAMS circled figures on the second board.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Six years ago, five, four, three! We’re making money, but there’s a drain, a slow leak. And-- He hustles the length of both boards, underlining figures

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Here. It. Is. She studies the name scrawled near the number.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Cambridge Manufacturing. (beat ) I’ve signed those checks.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Purchase order authorized by?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Ed. Mr. Chilton. Chris shrugs, only mildly interested in Ed, starts to spe

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: But we pay them every quarter. I’ve seen the parts. They’re electronic assemblies for the consumer division.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You saw somebody’s parts, probably decoy scrap from Taiwan, Juarez. (taps several figures) Notice anything? Her eyes ping-pong - nothing. He hints, taps the second number in an underlined figure, a “3.” She studies. He TAPS again, harder.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Second number in each is a three.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Human error. Most people, when asked to pick large numbers at random, rely on certain patterns. She stares at the board, touches his arm.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (smiles; looks at him) I was right?  51. Momentarily thrown by her touch, he recovers, steps away, struggles to re-establish eye contact, blinking.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’re guessing you reviewed income statements from two years ago. You saw Cambridge had been paid an amount for parts that exceeded what Creative was producing at the time. Call. No one will answer.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) I studied those ledgers for months. It was only one fiscal year. (beat) You went through ten. Overnight. He moves to the center of the boards and the EMPTY CIRCLE

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (excited) None of this is even the most interesting part of the--

dialogues.speaker: RITA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sharp) Cummings. Rita in the room, staring at the boards, taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I believe you’re needed in whatever area I’m paying you to be needed in. Dana checks Chris with an embarrassed glance, heads for t door, giving Rita an apologetic smile on the way out. Rita slowly approaches the boards, looks at Chris.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And? Chris points to circled figures, quickly adding in his he

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: One million, three hundred forty five... two million, three hundred ninety seven... four million... He ticks off the remaining eight circles as if they were elementary school math, doing impossible figures in secon

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Twenty million, seven hundred ninety nine thousand. (uncharacteristic) And some change.  52. Rita stiffens, nods.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Your best guess?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Chilton. She squares up to him, confrontational.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You or Mr. Black. She looks at him for a beat, the boards, turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You’1l have a report for me? He looks at her, away, then back, nods. INT. ED CHILTON’S HOME - BEDROOM - NIGHT Dark. Ed, pajamas and bed-head, shuffles across the large room. In bed, his wife sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed yawns, stands in front of his toilet, urinating. The sound of his urine stream stops, starts, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed heads back to bed. A faint NOISE outside the room. He stops, listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge river-stone fireplace anchors the home of a wealth man. Light from a plasma TV left on, volume low. Ed, ina long bathrobe, frowns at the TV. He kills it, heads for the--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light spills out from an open Sub-Zero. Ed rummages in th fridge for a snack.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (low) You’1l have the lemon meringue pie. Ed whirls around, frightened. Brax and two THUGS.  53. Brax waggles the barrel of a silencer-fitted hand-cannon the interior of the Sub Zero.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: And those two bottles of insulin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grouped on the kitchen table-- a wedge of lemon pie on a plate, two vials of insulin, a syringe. Brax and a nauseous Ed seated at the table, face each oth over the pie, medication. Thugs stand in the bg.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (checks watch; low) I would think you’d appreciate being treated like an adult. Bile rises in Ed’s throat. Brax motions to THUG 1, silent familiar shorthand. Thug 1 places a waste-basket next to Ed. The CFO retches into it, recovers. Brax signals for water.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: You administer an accidental insulin overdose, die with dignity, in the comfort of your home, your wife the beneficiary of, I assume, a generous insurance policy. Thug 1 delivers water and a paper towel. Ed takes a shaky drink, wipes his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I’m a master of the suicide scene but we’ll need the appearance of an accident if you want your wife to collect on the policy. If we lay hands on you you'll fight, squeal, she wakes up... (shrugs ) Then my hands are tied. One accidental death is just that. Two? I could stage a murder- suicide but you don’t fit the profile and quite honestly, sir, I have neither the will nor the inclination to do so. No, I’1l have little choice but to rock and roll a simple home invasion, violate your wife a dozen different ways, kill you both and burn this place to the ground.  54. At the mention of his wife, Ed’s eyes well with tears, ha involuntarily plead with the devil in his kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: (normal tone; grins) Any chance I go first, boss? Ed stifles a sob, cuts panicked eyes to the kitchen entry Brax turns in his seat, pins Thug 1 with a look that radi menace even in the dim light. Thug 1 averts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (back to Ed) Okay, settle down, nobody’s touching your wife. Aside from what it would say about me as a person, physiologically it’s a non- starter. No disrespect, I’m sure Mrs. Ed floats your boat but my taste leans to twenty-year old stripper. (sincere) So, I apologize. Sometimes I think I say shit just to sample what comes out of my mouth. Ed exhales, a grateful smile, chance of a reprieve. No go. Brax pulls his .45, uses the barrel to push the syringe to within a couple inches of Ed.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I will, however, park a forty-five in her brainpan. I honor my commitments. That’s who I am. A concept you and your sticky fingers obviously struggle with. Make a decision, sir. Realization dawns on Ed, resignation. INT. CREATIVE ROBOTICS - CHRIS’ OFFICE - DAY A MAINTENANCE WORKER, bucket at his feet, dutifully clean numbers off the wall. The dry-erase boards gone. Chris stands, stares at the board-less wall. On edge, his puzzle gone.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why do you do this, son? Chris turns. Lamar stands watching him, his eyes red, puf

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We’re good at it.  55. Lamar nods, considers the response. Not convinced.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Little doubt about that. He pulls a check from his shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: The balance of your contract. He sets it on the table, rubs his eyes, anxiety building.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Mr. Chilton is dead. And that makes you sad.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Very sad--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We haven’t finished.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Ed was a diabetic for the last thirty years. You think he didn’t know how to check his own blood sugar? No, whatever unresolved issues remain, my friend was poisoned enough by them to kill himself. As far as I’m concerned whatever he did is forgiven. He extends a hand. Chris looks at it, accepts, then grips Lamar’s forearm with his free hand, forces eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Sir. Please. We need to finish. Lamar is momentarily taken aback, searches Chris’ face, t realizes the depth of his need. Movement at the door, the two turn. Dana stands in the doorway, pale.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I'll come back--

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: Come in, dear. We’re finished. He removes himself from Chris’ hold, moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: (sympathetic smile) Mr. Wolff, you’re very good. But, I hope our paths don’t cross again. Lamar leaves, pausing to squeeze Dana’s shoulder.  56.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (to Chris; shaken) I heard what Mr. Black said. Do you think it’s true? That Mr. Chilton killed himself? It, it can’t be.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (distracted; sincere) It's difficult for us to say why people do what they do.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: But, doesn’t it bother you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Doesn’t what bother us?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: That we’re somehow, I don’t know... responsible. If I hadn’t--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why apologize for the truth? Dana is halted by his apparent indifference, disappointed

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Good-bye, Chris. Chris looks at her, searching for the right words. She walks out. He stares at the doorway, glances at the empty wall. INT. TREASURY BUILDING - RAY’S OFFICE - DAY Ray at his desk, transfixed by the images on his monitor- Raven surveillance. The Raven killer turns -- freezes.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (excited) That’s him, that’s the accountant. Marybeth sits in her usual chair, facing Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (bracing) A friend at Homeland. He holds the Antwerp photo, compares it to the monitor im  57.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (hesitates) You spoke with the officer in charge?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Seems unhappy in his work. Said to ask you why we stopped an investigation into someone who just killed nine men. Ray stands, walks to a tall file cabinet, slides open a middle drawer, fingers the folders, pulls an age-yellowed tabloid-size 1968 LIFE magazine.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: We were investigating the men he killed, not the killer.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: The mafia? He flips through the pages as he walks to his desk, folds open, hands it to her. She reads-- Marybeth’s POV: the heading: LA COSA NOSTRA. A B&W photo two older men flanked by a younger man, names captioned.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (reads; impressed) Carlo Gambino and Meyer Lansky.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: The third guy. The third man; a young Francis, handsome, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: “Unidentified man?”

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Francis Silverberg. He kept the books for the Gambino family for forty years. They were doing five hundred million tax-free dollars a year. In the sixties. (beat) He was Treasury property.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What’s your mafia I.Q? Low. She gestures noncommittally, Ray grins, interprets.  58.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Godfather, Goodfellas, first two hours of Casino? She smiles, off the hook, warming to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Name Albert Anastasia ring a bell?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Head of Murder Incorporated. Nicknames: the Mad Hatter, the Lord High Executioner. Anastasia also ran the Gambino family before it was the Gambino family. His under- boss was Carlo Gambino. You see where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: For Albert, poorly.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Anastasia was kill-crazy, paranoid, murdered mobsters and civilians alike. A liability to the brains running the show -- Lucky Luciano, Meyer Lansky -- but too powerful to risk killing. Francis was Anastasia’s accountant, cooked the books on all his rackets; extortion, loan-sharking, gambling, prostitution, right down to expensing the shave and haircut Albert treated himself to every other week at the Park Sheraton Hotel. Marybeth studies Francis’ image; intelligent, decent.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Anastasia got it in his head that Francis knew too much about his operation, arranged to have him clipped by unrecognizable out-of- town hitters. A cash retainer was paid to the Patriarca brothers out of Boston which Francis dutifully noted in his ledger. Marybeth listens, absorbed.  59.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: A week later, in the fall of fifty- seven, two masked men walked into the Park Sheraton barbershop and pumped six bullets into Albert Anastasia. The last words the Mad Hatter ever heard were-- (Boston accent) “So long, bean counter.” Quote and dropped ‘R’ supplied by the barber who had just obscured Anastasia’s face with hot lather.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (amazed) They thought he was Francis. He switched the hit.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Murder remains unsolved. But nobody ever fucked with Francis Silverberg again. Gambino took over with Francis as accountant and became the most powerful mobster in New York. Lansky and Francis laundered money all over the world. Then in the Spring of 2000 Francis walked into New York’s FBI headquarters, sat down and started talking. The acting boss of the family, Big Tony Benedetto thought Francis’ age made him vulnerable to prosecution. Ordered a hit. Francis sniffed it out. He was taken into protective custody... She stares at him, absorbed.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: ..-given immunity. The Bureau convicted Big Tony and two dozen other mobsters on Francis’ testimony. Then the Towers came down and everything changed. The Patriot Act allowed us to detain him indefinitely. F.B.I. farmed him out to Treasury to develop a link between mob money-laundering fronts and arms shipments to terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Who has him now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poorly lit. Cinder-block walls. A blood-smeared nail gun balanced on a saw horse.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bureaucracy. Paperwork mistake, I don’t know. One day he was just processed out. Francis, naked from the waist up, slumps in a straight-ba wooden chair, hands nailed to the chair’s arms. Blood streams from his scalp and pulped face, the gray hair on heaving chest matted with sweat, blood.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His fortune gone on his wife’s cancer treatments, no family, no friends. No options. Big Tony’s kid, Little Tony -- real original -- had him in less than four hours. Around him, FOUR MOBSTERS stand, laughing. A BLOW TORCH i lit. Francis strains against the nails. Cries.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Anyway, with Little Tony dead in the Raven slaughter, Treasury called off the investigation, shut down all wiretaps. Buried our fuck up with Francis. Tied it off. The story hangs in the air, Marybeth stares at the LIFE.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Name “Solomon Grundy” mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, unshaven, eyes red, sits alone, behind his desk. H stares into space, rocking back and forth, thinking. OS a phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (sotto; startled) Oh! Scared me to death. (into phone; answering) ZZZ Accounting. May I help you? (listens) Hold please. (to Chris; loud) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Wolff! Guy wants to know if we handle 401K roll-overs. He continues to rock, staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Wolff?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (subdued) Monday morning. Eight-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (to customer) Sir? Yes, we do. INT. CHRIS’ RANCH HOME - BASEMENT - NIGHT A STROBE-A-SCOPE fills the dark room with disorienting pulsing light. Deafening HARD ROCK plays. Chris -- shorts, no shirt -- hangs beneath an overhead I- beam, fingertips curled around the beam’s lip. He rips through pull-ups; upper legs held parallel to the floor, cinder block suspended between bare feet. Abs contract, veins cord. He is extraordinarily muscled. On his back, beneath a shoulder: a group of three nickel- sized starburst scars. Eyes squeezed shut, he WINCES in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nightstand clock rolls 10:01. A beat. Chris hurries in, soaked in sweat. He beelines for his bottle of PROZAC. He sits on the bed, stops. He considers the bottle, the pills inside. His grip tightens, resentment mounting. He ROARS in FRUSTRATION, fires the bottle at a wall. The bottle CRACKS open, capsules scatter. He squeezes his head between his forearms, fingers laced his head. He moans, rocks back and forth in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris’ pickup slows at a gravel driveway. He wheels in, passing a MAILBOX reading “RICE.”  62. EXT. RICE FARM —- DAY Parked at the base of a giant sycamore, Chris sits on the open gate of his pickup, Sharpie in hand, putting the finishing touches on the third smiley-face canteloupe. His Sharpie trails off mid-smile, mind elsewhere. He lays back.

dialogues.text: (to Thug 1; tentative) He’s too far... He won’t--

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Now. She rises, walks to the door. Thug 2 follows, gun drawn.

dialogues.text: (calls out) Christian! Chris!  64.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 2
dialogues.text: (jabs her with his gun) Again. Louder.

dialogues.text: Please! Don’t...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores stares at the decapitated corpse, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: (breathless; furious) Everybody thinks they’re tough with a gun. I get my hands on-- (opens the window) I‘1l show that pussy what t-- WHOOMP! He’s VACUUMED out the open window. Dolores looks around, suddenly alone. The house still.

dialogues.text: Chris’ arms encircle a prone Thug 1’s thick neck. Chris exerts pressure, whispers in the terrified big man’s ear.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Say “yes” when you hear the name of your employer. Practice.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: (gasps) Y... yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Solntsevskaya Bratva. Camorra. Gambinos. Juarez Cartel. No answer. Chris frowns, squeezes, the man purples.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You’ve a clear understanding of the rules? Thug 1 GASPS, forces a small nod.  66.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Treasury?

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: My pants pocket... left. Chris removes an arm, digs into the man’s pocket, comes o with a small photo of... DANA.

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: Do you both. That’s all--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: If we let you go, will you continue to try to kill us?

dialogues.speaker: THUG 1
dialogues.text: (trick question?) No?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS

Chris snags his wrist, breaks the arm, sinks the blade into the man’s che The dying man searches Chris’ face as he’s eased to the ground. INT. dialogues.text: (quick; into phone) Kill Christian Wolff. Transfer all domestic accounts offshore. Video-stream of the STORAGE LOT. He thumb-wipes the scree

dialogues.text: (over phone) Current vehicle?

dialogues.text: F-one-fifty.

dialogues.text: Boole. Obviously.

dialogues.text: Directions. CLICKING ebbs, resumes.

dialogues.text: Whoa! In a hurry, Mr. Wolff? Chris ignores him, grips the wheel, the muscles in his ar neck bunch as he stares straight ahead, out the windshiel The security bar lifts. Fifty yards from his trailer, his life.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Mr. Wolff? You al-- Chris EXPLODES, shaking the wheel, snarling, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: SHE IS NOT OUR PROBLEM
dialogues.text: INT. DANA’S APARTMENT BLDG. - LOBBY - DAY Dana, hair down, jeans and a t-shirt, enters the elevator carrying a bag of groceries, purse over a shoulder. Two large MEN enter the elevator. They move to the rear o the car, push no buttons. She hugs her groceries. The elevator doors close.  68.

dialogues.text: No, wait-- PHHT! PHHT! Chris double-taps him. FIGHT OVER. Amid spilled produce, a nearly crazed Dana still fumbles her keys, focused on opening her door. dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Dana. We must go. INT. CHRIS’ PICKUP TRUCK (MOVING VERY FAST) - DAY Chris drives, Dana in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (near hysterics) No! I don’t need you to protect me! We're going to the police! That's what normal taxpaying people do! Slow down!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: An hour ago, two men tried to kill us. Fifteen minutes ago, two men tried to kill you. Creative is our only common denominator. Whoever took that money wants us dead.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (talking over him) No, no, no, no, no, no.  70.

dialogues.text: We have one option; disappear.

dialogues.speaker: DANA

dialogues.text: The police can’t protect you from someone who had an extra twenty million dollars at their disposal.

dialogues.text: (on edge) No one person removes that much.

dialogues.text: Ex-military probably. The kind used to soft targets.
