dialogues.text: Soft?  71. Chris glances at her. She gets it.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: What will she do now?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Call the other kind. INT. O’HARE INTL. AIRPORT-GATE - DAY Brax sits, reads the Wall Street Journal. He scans the st index, locates his target, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT INTERCOM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Flight 121 to Turks and Caicos now seating our first class passengers. “I’ve got the world on a string, I’m sitting on a rainbow Got the string around my finger, what a world, what a lif

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. O’HARE INTL. AIRPORT-JETWAY - DAY Brax strolls, mobile phone to an ear. Irritated.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (into phone) Since when did accountants become difficult to ventilate? (surprised; amused) Dead? Christ, what did he do, hit them with an adding machine? Brax listens, slows, grin fading. He stops, his face empt oblivious to the luggage-toting travelers edging around h

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Give me the client’s number. I want to hear more about this accountant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana stutter-steps backward as Chris roll-slams the overh door down. Dark. Light sneaks in from the imperfect seal under and around the big metal door. She follows him to the trailer door. He jerks it open, st up, turns on her.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You wait here. He disappears inside, the door slams shut on a speechless Dana. Lights pop on within the trailer.  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, in a black fidget, hustles toward his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerves frayed, Dana hugs herself, paces, walks to the trailer, looks in a window. She resumes pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris SLAMS the door shut, pulls a bulging duffel from hi closet, dumps it onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana stops pacing, shakes her head. This is ridiculous. Heads for the trailer door.

dialogues.speaker: DANA AND CHRIS
dialogues.text: Chris unzips the duffel, double-checks the contents; clot cash, laptop, silencer-equipped pistol. Dana walks the trailer, scans her surroundings. Christmas tree lights, speakers... He digs a bottle of meds out of the duffle, shakes it to confirm the amount. She looks around, pulls open a drawer; knives, forks, spo LOOSE DIAMONDS. She slides the drawer shut. Pulls the pantry drawer out-- shrink wrapped Yen, Euros, dollars. Shoves it shut. He glances to the closed door, concerned. He rifles an op drawer full of neatly arranged PASSPORTS. Her face pressed to the port-hole window of the trailer’s Hauler room. A view of the gun racks, the PISTOL GRIP SHOTGUN, KALASHNIKOV, scoped Dakota. He slips into a clean shirt. A quick look around the room takes the Light Sabre down, hides it in the closet. Dana inspects the Renoir. Is this real? Her fingertips brush the canvas, down, his SIGNATURE. She recoils, the piece shifts slightly. She bangs the table, turns-- Looks down the barrel of a silenced 10 mm Glock, Chris on other end. She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (disintegrating rapidly) Who are you? He swallows, hesitates for a beat, torn by the desire to himself of the intruder in his sanctuary.  73.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be in here. He quickly lowers the gun, points to the kitchen seat.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Right there! Sit right there! She sits, he starts to leave, turns on her again.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Do not move!

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: My apartment. Those two men...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We've benefited from military training. He walks, she ignores orders and bolts up, follows.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Whose military?! (then; low) It was nothing for you. He groans, exasperated by her inability to follow directi

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We don’t approve of violence, but when it’s in self defense we call it intelligence. Moving quickly, he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris moves quickly around the motorcycle, Dana on his he He takes the SHOTGUN from the rack.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: That painting, those diamonds--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Payment. He pulls open a tool chest drawer... SHOTGUN SHELLS. He takes a box as an increasingly frantic Dana watches.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Payment? For what?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Services rendered.  74.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: What kind of accountant gets paid in Renoirs?!

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Our kind. We like Renoir.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: And those guns, why do-- He heads back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris motors, Dana following, crowding. His irritation me redlining, he rubs his head with his free hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: All tools. All math. Ballistics. Windage, elevation, velocity, loads. He brakes -- Dana nearly slamming into him -- adjusts the Renoir. He continues into--

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Math? I see, guns don’t kill people, math kills people? Chris works the shotgun and shells into the duffel.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We can’t hit a man with Fermat’s Last Theorem at a thousand yards, so, no, we'd say guns kill people.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Sarcasm? Is that sarcasm?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. It is not.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (unhinged; yells)

dialogues.speaker: WHY AREN'T YOU MORE UPSET
dialogues.text: He zips the duffel, turns, gives her his full attention.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: It’s the cost of doing business. But at this moment we need to move our home to a safe spot. Now. Decide, Dana. (beat) Are you safer with or without us?  75. She gapes at him, the painting on the ceiling catches her eye. She looks up, stares. He follows her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Tell me that’s not an original Pollock.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (confused by the request) What is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Marybeth sits at her desk, staring dry-eyed at her monitor. MUG SHOTS OF DOZENS OF MEN scroll. Louis “Lou” Carroll, Lew Carol, Louis Karel. She rubs her tired face, getting nowhere. She tap-tap-tap her fingertips on her desktop. Types ALBERT ANASTASIA. Black and white photo circa 1957: detectives in suits/hat take notes. At their feet, white sheets cover the face, lower body of a dead Anastasia, his bare-chested corpse o the tile floor of a barber shop. The mobster’s lifeless hand inches from a pool of blood. Desk phone RINGS. She jumps. Picks up.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (into phone) Marybeth.

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone; female) Ms. Medina, Tara Schneider, FBI Language Services.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Any luck?

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Interesting audio file. Solomon Grundy’s a nursery rhyme, dates back to the mid 1800s. Your voice has four of the six intonation patterns we use to define American English.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: There a “but” in there?

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But, difficult to confirm with a rhyme. Out of curiosity, was your subject a trauma victim?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Not that I know. Why?  76.

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You indicated on your submission this event occurred in a high stress environment?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Exceptionally.

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST
dialogues.text: The verse was repeated a total of four and a half times with zero variation in pitch span, tempo, volume, or articulatory precision. Zero.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: And that means what to me?

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST
dialogues.text: We often see this type of repetitive chanting in children who have been exposed to trauma or persons with neurodevelopmental disorders.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: “Neurodevelopmental disorders?”

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fragile-X syndrome, autism. Marybeth hangs her head, tired, getting nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: American then.

dialogues.speaker: FBI LINGUIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good luck. She hangs up, resumes tapping her fingers, has a thought. GOOGLES “Lou Carroll”. Nothing. Types in “Louis Carroll.” “DID YOU MEAN LEWIS CARROLL?” pops up. Sigh. Double-click. A sketch from Alice in Wonderland: the MAD HATTER, follow by a B&W photo of a slender man, Charles Dodgson circa la 1800s, his alias: LEWIS CARROLL. Text stands out: “AUTHOR OF ALICE’S ADVENTURES IN WONDERLAND.” “ASPERGER’S SYNDROME.” She clicks the ASPERGER’S link. Page after page of Asperg articles. She clicks one. “RUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER” pops. Marybeth straightens in chair, attention caught. She clicks back to Lewis Carroll scans the text: “PSEUDONYM,” “FICTITIOUS NAME”.  77. “MATHEMATICIAN.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Large. Cubicles. Overhead fluorescent lights off. Faint FOOTSTEPS. A lone light shines from a cubicle in the middle of the r SOUND OF AN ADDING MACHINE. A male IRS AGENT, 50s, starched white shirt, tie, flips through a file with one hand, works an adding machine wit the other. FOOTSTEPS approach. Stop. He looks up with sunken bloodhound eyes, a humorless smil

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) And how may the I.R.S. help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris’ pickup exits the lot. The Airstream parked, blendi in among two hundred RVs.

dialogues.speaker: DANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where do we go from here?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We get a place for the night.

dialogues.speaker: DANA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (surprised; self- conscious ) Oh. What, like a, a safe-house?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elegant low-key lighting illuminates its sign. Uniformed valets front its entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chic. Exclusive. Expensive. Behind a Japanese businessman Chris, duffel at his feet, stands next to Dana.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (low) I can’t afford this.  78.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: “Travel and Leisure” gives it a 97.5, the Four Seasons a 95.3. (pleased beat) Our treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marybeth and the IRS Agent sit side-by-side behind his de staring at his monitor. He works his mouse...

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: In the U.S., two hundred four men -- last name any standard derivation of Carroll -- reported over five hundred thousand dollars in any of the last seven years.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Go a million plus. He types in the new specs, hits ENTER.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: Thirty five. (scrolls down) Of those, seven are between the ages of twenty-five to forty-five. They both follow the tax forms.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Of those seven, only one has an income stream that’s cash heavy or can be readily laundered. And he-- (bangs the enter key) Died three years ago. The IRS Agent leans back, weary. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: “Sometimes it’s useful to know how large your zero is.” She hands him several sheets of paper.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Names of the one-hundred most famous mathematicians. She nods at him to get started. He stares, unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: What’s in it for me?  79.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: We find him? I’11 do whatever I can to get you out of here. He squints at the monitor, hands poised over his keyboard

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: First name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large. Luxurious. Stunning view of downtown Chicago. A low fire crackles in the fireplace. A sterling silver room-service tray holds the remains of dinner: hamburgers, fries, milk-shakes in tall glasses. In the center of the tray, long-stemmed orchids in a vase

dialogues.speaker: DANA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: None of this makes sense. Why go to the trouble of skimming money if you’re just going to put it back? Chris paces, Dana sits on a long couch.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: For the last two years, the amount of invoices submitted by Cambridge decreased.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Scared of getting caught?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) At the same time, sales increase dramatically in the consumer division but no inventory turns.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Price hike?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (frustrated; irritated) Prices of consumer electronics-- Go down, not up. Down.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Down. Sorry. Sorry. He sits next to her, rubs his legs, thinking, thinking. She kicks off her shoes, tucks her legs beneath her. She looks at him, reluctant to interrupt his thoughts.  80.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Those paintings? In your trailer. They’re real, aren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: The people who paid you with them. They didn’t buy them at auction. Did they?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: No. She nods, accepting.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: By the way... thank you. His concentration falters, breaks, he looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: At my apartment. Thanks. He nods, interrupts eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (struggles) How did you...? You know... She pantomimes firing a gun with her thumb and forefinger

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Our mom left us when we were ten. Father was an officer in the Army. Psychological Operations. Bangkok, Munich, Tel Aviv, Jordan. Thirty- two homes in seventeen years. She watches him stare into the middle distance, rememberi

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: He worried. He was afraid.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Of?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: What would happen to us without him. That one day he wouldn’t be there for us. So we learned things. From specialists. He glances at her, then away. Opening up difficult.  81.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: If we can’t master something, can’t solve a puzzle... (beat) We have a, a problem. He quick-checks her face to gauge a reaction... she smile

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: When I was a senior? In high school? (out on a limb) I wanted a special dress for prom. I know what you’re thinking-- She looks at him, face devoid of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Maybe not. Anyway, I told myself spending a few hundred dollars on some satin bridesmaid knockoff I'd wear once and to an event I thought was silly in the first place--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Impractical.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Aha! See? You get it. But Vera Wang on the other hand, she made a black strapless classic you could wear to all sorts of future events.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: An investment.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Yes! Where were you when I was in high school?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Israel. Maybe North Carolina. Becoming accustomed to him, she’s back on track.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Only problem? Six hundred dollars they wanted for that dress! She waits for the usual empathy face. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I didn’t have it, so--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You asked your parents?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: No, hang on--  82. He starts to hazard another guess.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Wait. Chastened, he waits. She gathers herself, dives in.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Blackjack. You know, twenty-one? He starts to question, she sees it coming--

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Never played a hand. Went to the library, checked out as many books as I could find on strategy. She stands, enthused, gesturing.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I turned the Naperville North math club into a little Vegas! I could tell you when to hit, stand, split, re-split, then moved on to card counting, shuffle tracking, even hole carding. She flops down on the couch, close to him. He notices.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I took my last hundred and eighty- three dollars and drove down to Harrahs in Joliet. She squares up to him, he squirms with the nearness of he

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I know what it means to obsess, Chris. To want something so entirely it becomes part of you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: The dress meant that much to you?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t about the dress. I wanted to walk into that gym and have people say “wow.” I just, I just wanted to fit in. You know? Belong. Everybody does. Their eyes meet. He knows, understands.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Lost all but twenty bucks in ten minutes. Fed the rest into nickel slots on the way out and won seven hundred dollars.  83. He smiles, his eyes dart from her eyes to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Paid for the limo. (beat) Wore the dress just the one time.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Why only once?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Never had a reason. In college my idea of fun was quiz bowls, art museums, speed math. Not sororities and such.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Speed math?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: You know, what’s... (dreams up a number) Two-hundred ninety-eight thousand, five hundred sixty seven times, I don’t know... ninety-two. The goal was to see how fa--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven million, four hundred sixty eight thousand, one hundred sixty four. She stares at him for a dumbfounded beat.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: That's so incredibly sexy. She blushes, nervous-laughs, both avoid eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I... How do you do that? He searches for the words, wanting to share.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We see it. She waits for the explanation, patient...

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Each number has its own shape. Like a musical note. They form patterns. (thoughtful beat) We can hear them. A rhythm, a beat. Some fast, some slow. All familiar. Always there. She’s entranced, drawn to him.  84.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Chris, why did we come here?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) They respect our privacy.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: The Holiday Inn Express in Aurora respects our privacy too.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We like nice hotels. She starts to speak, he cuts her off--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: They’re clean, quiet, no one bothers us, good water pressure-- (beat) We thought you'd like it. She puts a tentative hand on his. He lets her. Encouraged she touches his face, strokes his cheek. He compels himse to make and keep eye contact. She leans in--

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Crazy Eddie and the Panama Pump. Stop. He bolts up, relieved and renewed. His puzzle solve

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Crazy Eddie Antar! Ran a chain of electronics stores on the East Coast back in the ‘80s, Crazy Eddie's. Started skimming money almost from the day his first store opened.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I’m not following you.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: He deposited millions in skimmed money into bank accounts in Tel Aviv then laundered them through Panamanian shell companies that drafted money into his stores.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Why? Why would he take it out just to put it back?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: He started skimming and hiding like anyone else does, to avoid taxes. But after several years, he had a better idea. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As soon as he stopped taking money his profit margin rose. When the laundered funds from Panama hit the books it looked like it was raining cash. She stands, turned on by his problem solving, his enthusi

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Public perception.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: (nods; smiling) Eddie took the company public at eight dollars a share. A year later it was trading at seventy- five. He put twenty-five million back in and made ten times that. They meet in the center of the room, close.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Rita’s taking Creative public. But why would she hire you in the first place if she thought you'd figure it out?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We'll ask.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: “We” as in you and I? Or...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corncob-shaped twin towers, sixty-five stories high. INT. CHRIS’ PICKUP TRUCK Parked a block from the Towers. Chris, ear-piece in, alon gloved hands screw a suppressor onto his semi-automatic.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You’re really pissing me off, you know that? Leave. Chicago. Now.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: If we don’t act, Dana will die.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE
dialogues.text: You don’t know that. Please.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Francis knew it.  86. INT. RITA’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - NIGHT Rita, in a nightgown, reading glasses, sits at a small de studying financials. A slight NOISE outside the room. She opens a drawer on the desk, pulls a .38. She deftly p the cylinder, checks the loads, wrist-snaps it shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita thunders down the darkened hallway, gun in hand.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (loud; grins) Please, God, let somebody be in my apartment that doesn’t belo-- PHHT! A silenced round slams into her forehead. She drops In the darkness, a mobile phone lights up as it’s flipped open. The owner brings it to his ear. BRAX. INT. LAMAR’S HOME - KITCHEN Lamar sits at a granite counter, humming, typing on a_ la interfaced with a PROSTHETIC HAND. A finger twitches-- His mobile RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: (into phone; avuncular) Yes, hello?

dialogues.speaker: BRAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) Done, you sick twist. The line GOES DEAD. Lamar exhales, returns his phone to h pocket, leans on the counter. He cries. Softly at first, then, overcome with grief, sob The tears quickly subside. He clears his eyes, wipes his nose. He focuses on his laptop, begins to type, tinker with the hand, humming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris stands on the curb ready to cross the street. He se a man exit the Towers, walking fast, staying in the shado Possible recognition plays across Chris’ face. Chris paces the man on the opposite side of the four lane street. Traffic passes between them. On the other side, Brax walks, his peripheral vision catc Chris’ figure on the opposite sidewalk, behind parked car  87. Brax stops. Chris stops. Brax resumes his pace, grins to himself. PHHT! PHHT! -- snaps off two NO-LOOK rounds across the street. A car win shatters. ALARM sounds. He looks... Chris is gone. Brax pauses, impressed with the vanishing act. INT. RITA’S APARTMENT - HALLWAY - NIGHT Dark. Rita’s lifeless body lies on the floor, eyes open, dime-size hole in the forehead. Chris squats next to her, forearms on his legs, gun held between his knees. He blinks back eye contact as he close her lids with a gloved hand.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT, (PRE-LAP V.O.)
dialogues.text: (exhausted; typing) Last one... Wolff, two “F’s"”, Christian. Her eyes closed, he looks at her face, rises quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IRS Agent enters the name, stares red-eyed at his monitor At his side, Marybeth slumps in her chair, list in hand.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: Two-hundred forty-five men. Four with incomes over a million. And-- She straightens in her chair, hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: All over the age of sixty. Sorry. She melts, sleep deprived, pressured, at her breaking poi

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: Didn't you mention that your guy was an accountant? He highlights two names. She slowly lifts her head.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: Two Christian Wolff's list their occupations as CPA’s. Both make over four-hundred thousand. (types) The first Christian Wolff owns Wolff Accounting, 121 south street, Scottsdale, Arizona. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (types; enters) The other Christian Wolff-- (puzzled) ZZZ Accounting? Wabash way, Plainfield, Illinois. Not exactly a smart Yellow Pages move. She lurches over him, commandeers his keyboard, pulls up GOOGLE EARTH, fingers pop keys. The Earth rotates-- Above the U.S., then Illinois, descends: 2Z2Z Accounting from an overhead view. She types, street level view. Marybeth’s POV: Z2Z Accounting. Kim’s Nails. Mandarin Garden Chinese Food. Al’s Laundromat.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Who filed the returns for Kim's Nails, Wabash Way, Plainfield? He scoots his chair to an adjacent work station, types. S kneels at his monitor, stares with screen-burned eyes.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: ZZZ Accounting. Could just be the neighborly--

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Mandarin Garden, Wabash.

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT
dialogues.text: ZZZ Accounting. Al’s laundromat-- (types; beat) ZZZ Accounting.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (emotional) Tell me they’re all registered as partnerships. She waits, breath held. Sound of him typing... then quiet

dialogues.speaker: IRS AGENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Every one. Managing partner... Christian Wolff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faint sound of a vacuum cleaner. Deserted save for a lone cleaning woman in the bg. Ray, Brooks Bros. suit, strides through his empire, folde Washington Times in one hand, Starbucks in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, sans jacket, lowers himself into his chair, starts h morning routine. He opens the Times, sips his coffee--  89. BAM! His door bangs open, startling him, spilling coffee. Marybeth steams in, clothes wrinkled, circles under her e

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Jesus H. Christ, Medina!

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Christian Wolff! She circles the desk, slaps a list down on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Christian Wolff, last year ran $447,543 through his accounting firm--

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Slow down. Who is Christian Wolff?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: The Accountant. For the first time, Ray appears off balance, he recovers.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Four-forty seven? No, no, chump change.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (hovers over him) Agreed. But he ran another $287,765 through Kim’s Nails, $345,112 at the Mandarin Garden, and -- you’ll love this -- $756,999 through Al’s Laundromat. Al’s Laundromat?! Are you kidding me? He’s playing with us! Ray skeptically reviews the list.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: “ZZZ",.  Why-- She straightens, paces, punchy from lack of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Because he doesn’t care about traffic, it’s a front, all these companies are in the same strip mall south of Chicago! “Christian Wolff,” “Lou ‘Lewis’ Carroll.” He’s using names of famous mathematicians as cover!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: There are famous mathematicians? (reads ) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charitable deduction to Harbor Neuroscience Institute? One point five million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: I don’t know, why do these whack jobs do anything?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Let me know how that rationale goes over with the judge you ask to issue the warrant.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: I got him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: All that’s still less than what? Two million? And he’s giving away almost all of it?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: What if he’s taking other means of payment... drugs maybe--

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (warming to it) Diamonds. She looks at him, expectant. Ray turns it over in his hea

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Freshen up fast. We’re going to Chicago. Move it. She bolts out the door, energized. He drops heavily into his chair, thinks for a beat, gnaws thumbnail, wipes at his coffee stain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris, jeans and jacket, sits on the edge of an easy chai rocking back and forth. He watches Dana sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOZEN KIDS cluster -- 10, 11, 12 years old -- a SLAP!

dialogues.speaker: BULLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: C’mon, pussy. Young Boy picks broken glasses from the ground, stands... nose bleeding, he faces--— BULLY, 12, thick in the chest, brow.  91.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY
dialogues.text: Not so smart out here are you? Bully slaps Young Boy in the side of the head. Young Boy tries to side-step, walk away. A second Bully blocks his way, herds him back.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY
dialogues.text: How ‘bout some of that “we” and “us”, huh? I can’t get enough of your batshit weirdness.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s not weird. Knot of kids parts as Little Brother steps in, passes Bul and stands with his older brother.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: And he’s not gonna hit you because he promised our father he wouldn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY
dialogues.text: Guess your old man’s as big a fag as he is.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s not it. See he broke a kid’s skull in Berlin. Young Boy puts his broken glasses on, blinks.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: Put a grown-up in the hospital in Thailand. (to Young Boy) Thailand? Young Boy wipes his nose, glances up, averts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: (to Bully) Let’s call it Thailand. Bully rotates his shoulders, prepares to brawl.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY
dialogues.text: Let’s see what he’s got. Little Brother smiles, turns to his brother. The world reduced to the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: It’s never going to change. You know that, don’t you? Young Boy looks at his younger brother, eye contact easy.  92.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: (to Bully) In Vietnam I watched a murder of crows -- that’s a “flock” to you illiterates -- surround a lamb. Then the meanest crow pecked out the little lamb’s eyes. The lamb went into shock, laid down, and the crows ate it alive. The crowd of children exchange uneasy looks.

dialogues.speaker: BULLY
dialogues.text: So now I’m a crow picking on your little lamb brother? Little Brother lunges forward, spears a thumb into one of Bully’s eyes. Bully SCREAMS, the crowd flinches, shrinks back. Little Brother whips his other thumb into the kid’s remaining ey the Bully drops, crying. CHILDREN SCATTER. Little Brother straddles the prone Bully, grabs a fistful hair. A bloody fist cocked, lips curled, he hisses--

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: No, motherfucker, I’m the crow, you're the lambs. He punches, savage, little arm like a piston. He glances at his older brother.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BROTHER
dialogues.text: It sucks, but sooner or later, everybody hates different. Little Brother continues his work. Young Boy’s eyes well with tears, he gazes through broken lenses, watches alarmed teachers sprint towards them.

dialogues.speaker: RETURN TO
dialogues.text: Chris’ rocking slows, stops. A yearning in his eyes, sadness.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Chris carefully places a folded sheet of paper next to a sleeping Dana. Gently touches her face. Touches his finge to his own face. He takes a long last look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana sits on the side of the bed, eyes red, open sheet of paper in hand. She stares straight ahead... at nothing.  93. Written on the sheet of paper: “I’m leaving. Goodbye Dana INT. CHRIS’ RANCH HOME - DAY Marybeth snaps on a pair of latex gloves, holds a wrinkle pair out to Ray. He shakes his head, scopes the room.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Won’t matter. Three FBI AGENTS wearing FBI jackets and latex gloves, ro

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Thanks for tying it down, Pat.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT-IN-CHARGE
dialogues.text: We’ve been here twenty minutes, might as well be twenty hours.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Computers?

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT-IN-CHARGE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No bills, magazines, TV, dirty dishes. If somebody did live here, they’ve got no reason to come back. Ray wanders, looking around, pensive.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Phone?

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT-IN-CHARGE
dialogues.text: Works. Registered to Christian Wolff. Phone company has no record of outgoing or incoming calls, not even tele-marketers.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (loud; from the kitchen) In here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VELCRO SEPARATES. FBI AGENT 1 carefully retrieves a pisto from the open cupboard. Agents watch.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT 1
dialogues.text: -357 Colt Python. Serial numbers gone. Agent 1 flips the cylinder open, looks.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT 1
dialogues.text: Hydra-Shok Magnums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marybeth looks at Ray. He seems in a trance, ignoring the gun, fascinated by the cabinets’ spare contents. EXT. CHRIS’ RANCH HOME - DAY Ray and Marybeth survey the property. He turns to the com ground, the woods beyond.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: This is our guy.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Why would a man who’s been up to his elbows in cash, live here? The automatic garage door lifts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agents file in, look around. The space bare but for-- The TARP-COVERED OBJECT suspended from the rafter beam.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: It’s the smart move. Given his clientele, he figures blending in will extend his shelf life. Ray jerks a thumb over a shoulder toward the common groun

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: The woods would bother me. No protection if-- An agent pulls off the tarp: a huge 6-BARREL MINI-GUN suspended in mid-air, pointed at Ray and Marybeth.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT-IN-CHARGE
dialogues.text: Jesusmaryandjoseph. Agent 2 pushes the heavy gun. It glides smoothly across t garage, links of 7.62 mm ammo uncoil, trail behind.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Don’t see that every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prone SNIPER 1 blends with brush, eye to his rifle scop His POV: Lake Michigan frames an isolated glass and brush steel mansion.

dialogues.speaker: SNIPER 1
dialogues.text: (into earpiece) Nope, all clear.  95. EXT. LAMAR’S BOAT HOUSE - DAY SNIPER 2 set up behind a tarp covered boat, scopes the re of the estate.

dialogues.speaker: MERC LEADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over earpiece) Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: SNIPER 2
dialogues.text: (into earpiece) Nothing but blue skies, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soaring vaulted cathedral ceilings, floor to ceiling wind MERC LEADER grins, glances at an anxious Lamar staring ou picture window. Four other MERCS lounge on furniture, loa clips, work slides on suppressor-equipped pistols.

dialogues.speaker: MERC LEADER
dialogues.text: (into earpiece) He'll wait for night. If at all. (disconnects) Gotta tell ya, Brax. Your call surprised me. After our little dustup in Tikrit, I kinda thought you’d be gunnin’ for us. Brax aims a remote at a high-end stereo system, music changes, classical, advertisement, country, rock.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Who knows what remains of the day?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: He’s only an accountant. You should be watching his home.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: I recommended you leave the country. You declined. An angry frightened Lamar turns on Brax.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: He’s a number-cruncher! He turns back to the window, regretful, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR
dialogues.text: I could see it in his eyes. The freak wasn’t going to let it go. Brax tenses at “freak”, turns the music off.  96. INT. CHRIS’ RANCH HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY A frustrated Marybeth leans against the couch, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: FBI AGENT-IN-CHARGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No problem, Ray. OS the front door SHUTS. Ray enters the room, drops onto couch, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I was old ten years ago. Ray slouches, loosens his tie, kicks his shoes off, puts feet up on the coffee table. His aura dims.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What’s your story, Medina?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: You know my story.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I know what the court said.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Hypothetically? He nods, patient. A long beat, a painful memory. She sits

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: I was a soldier in a Baltimore street crew. At seventeen I might have pistol-whipped my sister's hypothetical pimp within an inch of his life. Somehow he wound up in the trunk of my hypothetical car. I kept him there for three days. Tension in the air, silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Regret it?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Only that I did it in the parking lot of a 7-Eleven with functioning security cameras. Ray doesn’t respond, waits for the real answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: My sister’s now a dental hygienist in Annapolis. Married, three kids. No, I don’t regret it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: That’s a rough hypothetical.  97. Enough. She turns a cold stare on him, cuts his strings.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Deputy Director King... what the fuck do you know about rough?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Well, hell, Marybeth, you tell me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horns HONK, brakes SCREECH.

dialogues.speaker: FEDERAL AGENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (at a distance; shouts) Wait, let me call it in! Muted pops of gunfire. Fast footfalls on the pavement. Guns drawn, backs to us, men run, pass two dead thugs on the sidewalk, pooling blo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUD GUNFIRE. A fear-stricken Don grips his gun, looks across the hall at his back-up -- RAY KING. Ray licks his lips, advances.

dialogues.speaker: DON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuck this. Let’s go. Ray looks, sees a terrified Don eyeing the entrance door.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Uh-uh, not me-- Don exits. BOOM! A shotgun blast. Ray automatically swivels to the sound, both hands grasp an unsteady gun he in front of him. A warren of rooms. Don hesitates, considers following, but instead runs for entrance door. Ray looks up. From the second floor SHOUTS OF PANICKED ME RUNNING.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had no business being in there. He approaches a doorway, swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sweeps the room with his pistol. Early Elk’s Lodge, small bar, a few tables. Stopping on--  98.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Put me in that 7-Eleven of yours with a cherry Slurpee and a stack of ones bleached to look like fives... I’m hell on wheels. A MOBSTER sits on the floor, back to the bar, head lolls the side, two bullet holes in his face. From the second floor A PUMP SHOTGUN BOOMS and reloads. AUTOMATIC GUNFIRE responds. Ray spots a staircase.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (sober) Not in there. Not with people like that. Like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No gunfire. No cursing. Only unsettling quiet. Ray advances down the dim hall. Sweating, hands trembling shoulders aching, labored breath loud in his ears. Blood-spatters spiderweb the walls on both sides. Dead mobsters litter the floor. Ray GASPS, startled. At his feet, a DYING MOBSTER with a gaping chest wound grips Ray’s pant cuff.

dialogues.speaker: DYING MOBSTER
dialogues.text: (weak rasp) Please. Help... Ray jerks the leg free, wipes flop-sweat from his eyes. From a room at the end of the corridor... a desperate, frightened voice.

dialogues.speaker: BENEDETTO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stop! You’re not hearing me. I wasn’t even there! I didn’t touch that old man-- Sound of a THWACK. A THUMP. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Little Tony Benedetto. I’d been sitting in a cramped van for six months listening to the arrogant son of a bitch belch, fart, and brag. (beat) Didn't recognize his voice with all the fear in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray inches along the wall to the doorway, pistol tight against his chest. He licks dry lips, tenses, ready... CLICK. A .45 cocks. Ray freezes. A barrel pressed against the ba of his head. He squeezes his eyes shut. Opens them.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (wounded; whisper) Your name?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (trembling; hoarse) Ray. Raymond King. OS the faint sound of POLICE SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who employs you, Raymond King? A fat drop of Chris’ blood hits the thin industrial carpe

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I... I’m a Treasury Agent.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you a good one?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Not particularly. No.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I’m married. Was married. The barrel digs into Ray’s skull.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: (desperate; emotional) A dad, I’m a dad. I have two kids.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Grown? Ray chokes back an involuntary sob, nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yes. They’re all, all grown up. Another drop of blood adds to a spreading carpet stain.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Were you a good dad? Ray King? He blinks back tears, sure of death. He remembers, smiles  100.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I’ve been a good dad. Been a lousy agent and, and a weak man, but that... That I didn’t screw up. That I did right. The sirens LOUDER. Closer. Ray waits. Death or a question. Seems like an eternity, but... NOTHING. He turns, the hallway empty of life. He slides down the wall, a pant leg stained with urine, still holding his gu He puts his face in his hands, CRIES with relief.

dialogues.speaker: RETURN TO
dialogues.text: Marybeth gapes at Ray, a question in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Suppose you were a Treasury agent in the twilight of a spectacularly dismal career...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A microwave cooks a breakfast burrito. An unshaven, wrink shirted Ray holds a five dollar bill up to the overhead fluorescent lights, studies it.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You tell yourself you’re justifying two failed marriages and a fondness for malt liquor by doing the least possible amount of work necessary to hang onto your pension. But that’s not true. The reality is, you lack both talent and ambition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windowless, dingy. Francis sits at a long oblong table, talks, doing his best to explain. He pauses, worried.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then one day... that break you should've been looking for. Sitting opposite Francis, an uninterested Ray puts pencil paper, nods his understanding, doodles.  101.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Made the new handler for an asset that could turn your career around if only you’d listen. You don’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A numb Francis wears a dated suit. He stands, waiting, ch suitcase by his feet. The bus pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You recommend he be released. Maybe even believe you’re doing him a favor. You’re not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coroner pulls back a sheet, averts his eyes from an uns corpse. An ashen Ray stares down. The sheet returned. One of Francis’ ruined hands is exposed. Ray’s eyes shine he takes the hand in his, gently tucks it beneath the she

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (emotion rising) So you volunteer for a joint task force, sit in a hot stinking surveillance van for months and wait for a shred of evidence to use against the old man’s killers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Don sit, the cramped space full of electronics. Visible through the windshield, CHRIS WALKS BY, unnoticed

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hardest thing to accept? After all that? If Don hadn’t charged in like an idiot, I wouldn’t have had the balls to step foot in the place. I was in the wrong place, wrong time. Changed my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray advances down the Raven’s corpse-strewn corridor.  102.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two months later, a call. Out of the blue. I’11 never forget the voice.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH TO
dialogues.text: INT. RAY’S CUBICLE - DAY The space tiny, fit for a bottom-feeder. A rheumy-eyed unshaven Ray answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) Do you like puzzles, Raymond King?

dialogues.speaker: RETURN TO
dialogues.text: INT. CHRIS’ RANCH HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY A speechless Marybeth watches Ray wrap it up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Tells me she works for the accountant. That a shipping container packed with Chinese nationals is passing through the Port of New York. Four months later, one ton of uncut Juarez Cartel product is entering Miami. So on, so forth. She leans back, overwhelmed, at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: All those cases you put together. The legend of Ray King.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Smoke. He doesn’t exist.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Who is he, this “accountant”?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: A.P. Hood, no middle name. American, thirty-one years old. We sprung him from Leavenworth maximum security.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: The military prison?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: He was with the Combat Applications Group out of Ft. Bragg. Hood’s a math savant, speaks Arabic, five or six others. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was assigned rendition work at black sites in Europe until he nearly beat an over- eager CIA interrogator to death and went AWOL. We requisitioned him to track Al Qaeda and Hamas money launderers. He roomed with Francis at our detention center. I’ve heard stories of him running a dozen Venn diagrams at once, did the work of five analysts. (beat; remembering) The day Francis’ body was found, Hood fractured his handler’s skull with a coffee thermos and just... walked away. Disappeared. (beat) I gave up trying to figure out when she’ll call. The “why” though, that I’ve got. Every case the same thread; an accountant is hired, someone whose skills far exceed the norm. Does the job in record time--

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (connecting the dots) They try to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: And I get a call. She bolts from the couch, overwhelmed, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me this? You never should have let anyone near this!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Least of all you.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes, least of all me!

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I told you when you started, I retire in a few months. (beat) She’1l need someone to call. She finally gets it. Digs her heels in.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: He’s a criminal! What about the ones that don’t try to kill him, the ones he doesn’t turn in? He aids and abets drug cartels, money launderers-- He killed all those men at the Raven!  104.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Murderers! How long did you have a trunk-full of pimp?

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Not even in the same league! He lets her cool, understands her anger, confusion.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I realized something that day. Sitting in my cubicle, trying to make this same decision. (beat) I'd spent the better part of my life recognizing my lucky breaks only after they were gone. She digests this for a beat, wavers.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: Any idea on the woman? The Brit? RING! Kitchen phone loud. She looks to Ray. RING! INT. CHRIS’ HOME-KITCHEN RING! Marybeth picks up the phone, answers.

dialogues.speaker: MARYBETH
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? From the other connection a KEYBOARD CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over phone) Agent Medina, pleased to meet you. Tell Eliot Ness to get his feet off the furniture. He’s not in a barn. Marybeth’s face drops, she looks for the camera.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH FEMALE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Creative Robotics. Write it down. INT. LAMAR’S HOME - FOYER - NIGHT Lights out. Moonlight through picture windows. Shadows. Merc Leader keeps watch through the front door’s sideligh The distant CRACK of a rifle shot. The room responds, Mercs stand, advance rounds. Lamar loiters, unsure what to do, looks to Brax.  105.

dialogues.speaker: MERC LEADER
dialogues.text: (into earpiece) Ike, was that you? Ike? EXT. LAMAR’S BOAT HOUSE - NIGHT Sniper 2 dead on the deck, hair wet with blood, head-shot

dialogues.speaker: SNIPER 1, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over earpiece) No. INT. LAMAR’S HOME - FOYER - NIGHT Brax joins Merc Leader at the opposite sidelight.

dialogues.speaker: MERC LEADER
dialogues.text: (into earpiece) Bobby, you there...? Brax gives Merc Leader a look, starts away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris lies on his stomach, comm-link in his ear, scopes Lamar’s home with a rifle identical to Sniper 1’s.

dialogues.speaker: MERC LEADER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (over earpiece) Bobby-- Chris taps the comm-link, disconnects. Next to him, a hog tied Sniper 1, his face bloodied.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: Felt like it pulled left--

dialogues.speaker: SNIPER 1
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Chris kneels, produces a rolled Persian rug. 17th century

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: You might consider a round with a superior ballistic coefficient. Sniper 1 watches Chris unroll the rug-- the Barrett .50 c

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: We need the layout of the home. Rooms, corridors, cover. INT. LAMAR’S HOME-LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Silent. Brax tucks into an interior doorway, pulls Lamar next to him. Brax eyes about, watches a BALD MERC edge across the room, into a beam of moonlight.  106.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: (to Lamar; low) Ever see a match-grade round traveling three thousand feet per second come through a window? A picture window divots, a mist from Bald Merc’s head. A distinctive BOOM from the Barrett, Bald Merc crumples.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: Nobody does. Brax grabs Lamar by the scruff of the neck, bolts. Mercs crouch as .50 cal rounds blow jagged holes through great room, brick powders, walls tear like tissue, strike lake beyond. A round punches thru 2 walls, a MUSTACHED ME A HUGE MERC lies flat, a round gouging the wood floor nea his head. The other Mercs crawl to the rear of the house. Stop. Silence. dialogues.text: (screams ) Enough with the moronic chant already! Chris squints against the light, pistol aimed at Brax. He hesitates, is kicked in the face, spun off Merc Leader. A enraged Brax looms over a prone Chris.

dialogues.speaker: BRAX
dialogues.text: You crack a spook’s skull?! Chris tries to rise, Brax kicks him.

dialogues.text: (near tears) You call me. Me. I’m your brother. I’m the one who always had your back. I fix things. Why didn’t you call me? Chris grabs Brax’ face in his hands, wills him to underst

dialogues.text: Statistically speaking not as--

dialogues.text: Dana discovered a weakness. You hired us to leak-test the books. Show you what wouldn’t stand up to public scrutiny. Chris stares at Lamar for a beat. Satisfied.
